content: The "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996" aims to protect citizens from armed violent criminals by focusing on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating offenders to prevent them from quickly returning to the streets. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force considers severe punishment, laws on apprehension and prosecution, available resources, and the nature of violent crime. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force considers resources, nature of violent crime, and limited Federal involvement in prosecution. The Attorney General requires monthly reports on defendants charged with violating specific laws and biannual reports on waivers granted. The Department of Justice provides information on waivers granted to United States attorneys for waiving certain requirements. The Attorney General can waive these requirements based on established guidelines considering the number of assistant attorneys and level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of violating a specific federal law. The term "armed violent criminal" refers to a person accused of violating specific federal laws related to previous violent crime convictions. This section will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Repeal of prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Various sections of title 18, United States Code, are amended to remove restrictions on certain firearms and ammunition. SEC. 5. Mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. This section imposes mandatory prison terms for specific firearm-related offenses. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentences range from 5 to 20 years depending on the actions taken with the firearm. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates additional prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentences vary from 10 to 30 years depending on the type of firearm and the circumstances of the offense. The sentences vary from 10 to 30 years depending on the type of firearm and the circumstances of the offense. If a firearm is brandished or discharged during a second offense, the person will face imprisonment for not less than 25 or 30 years respectively. If the firearm is a machinegun or destructive device, the sentence will be life imprisonment. Probationary sentences are not allowed for violations of this subsection. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code prohibits probationary sentences for those convicted of possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Additionally, individuals sentenced under this subsection cannot be released for any reason during their imprisonment. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on March 22, 1996.
